lines.text: Articles in English Grammar
Writing Centre Learning Guide
The words ‘a’, ‘an’ and ‘the’, known as articles , present problems for most speakers
of English as an additional language. This is not surprising, since there is no

spans.text: of English as an additional language. This is not surprising, since there is no

lines.text: equivalent construction in many languages, and those languages that do have

spans.text: equivalent construction in many languages, and those languages that do have

lines.text: articles do not necessarily use them in the same way as English.

spans.text: articles do not necessarily use them in the same way as English.

lines.text: Introduction
It is often difficult to decide whether an English noun needs an article before it, and, if so, which

spans.text: It is often difficult to decide whether an English noun needs an article before it, and, if so, which

lines.text: article (a/an/the) to use. The main things to consider when choosing an article are whether or not

spans.text: article (a/an/the) to use. The main things to consider when choosing an article are whether or not

lines.text: the noun is countable, and whether it is definite. Countability means that the noun can be made

spans.text: the noun is countable, and whether it is definite.
means that the noun can be made

lines.text: plural, e.g. book/books . This is something you can check in a learner’s dictionary of English.

spans.text: . This is something you can check in a learner’s dictionary of English.

lines.text: Whether a noun is definite or indefinite depends on whether you and your reader or listener both

spans.text: Whether a noun is definite or indefinite depends on whether you and your reader or listener both

lines.text: know what you are referring to. The following pages give you some guidelines on what makes a

spans.text: know what you are referring to. The following pages give you some guidelines on what makes a

lines.text: noun countable and/or definite. Much of the information is based on the work of Master (1986) and

spans.text: noun countable and/or definite. Much of the information is based on the work of Master (1986) and

lines.text: Swales and Feak (1994).
When you have to decide whether to use an article, and which article to use, consider this chart:

spans.text: When you have to decide whether to use an article, and which article to use, consider this chart:

lines.text: Choosing the right article
Is the noun singular and countable? Is the noun plural or uncountable?

spans.text: Is the noun singular and countable?
Is the noun plural or uncountable?

lines.text: Yes
Is it definite? Is it definite?
yes no yes no
the a/an the no article
For example:
I bought a book – book is a singular, countable noun; therefore it has to have an article.

spans.text: is a singular, countable noun; therefore it has to have an article.

lines.text: Your reader does not know which book you are referring to, therefore it is ‘indefinite’.

spans.text: Your reader does not know which book you are referring to, therefore it is ‘indefinite’.

lines.text: The book I bought is interesting - book is again a singular, countable noun; therefore it has

spans.text: The book I bought is interesting
is again a singular, countable noun; therefore it has

lines.text: to have an article. In this case, we know which book you are referring to (the book you

spans.text: to have an article. In this case, we know which book you are referring to (the book you

lines.text: bought), so it takes a definite article. (More details on the definite article are given

spans.text: bought), so it takes a definite article. (More details on the definite article are given

lines.text: below.)
I like the books you gave me – books is a plural noun. It is used in a definite sense (we

spans.text: like the books you gave me
is a plural noun. It is used in a definite sense (we

lines.text: know which books – the books you gave me), so it takes a definite article.

spans.text: know which books – the books you gave me), so it takes a definite article.

lines.text: I like books – books is a plural noun. It is used about books generally, not specific books,

spans.text: is a plural noun. It is used about books generally, not specific books,

lines.text: so it takes no article.
Blood is thicker than water – blood and water are singular, uncountable nouns. They are

spans.text: are singular, uncountable nouns. They are

lines.text: used in a general sense, therefore they do not need an article.

spans.text: used in a general sense, therefore they do not need an article.

lines.text: I bought two books – you do not need an article, because you already have the word two .

spans.text: – you do not need an article, because you already have the word

lines.text: I bought some books – you do not need an article, because you already have the word

lines.text: some .
How do you know whether you need an article and which article to use?

spans.text: How do you know whether you need an article and which article to use?

lines.text: A single, countable noun must have an article if there is no other number, determiner or

spans.text: A single, countable noun must have an article if there is no other number, determiner or

lines.text: possessive (e.g. two , our, this ). If the noun is plural, an article may not be necessary. Look first at

spans.text: ). If the noun is plural, an article may not be necessary. Look first at

lines.text: your noun:
our house – you do not need an article, because you already have the possesive our .

spans.text: – you do not need an article, because you already have the possesive

lines.text: this year – you do not need an article, because you already have the determiner this .

spans.text: – you do not need an article, because you already have the determiner

lines.text: car – you need an article, because this is a singular countable noun with no determiner

spans.text: – you need an article, because this is a singular countable noun with no determiner

lines.text: already.
trees – you may need an article, depending on whether the noun is definite or not.

spans.text: – you may need an article, depending on whether the noun is definite or not.

lines.text: For example:
Trees are usually green – no article is needed, because you are talking generally and

spans.text: – no article is needed, because you are talking generally and

lines.text: the noun is not definite, i.e. you are not talking about specific trees.

spans.text: the noun is not definite, i.e. you are not talking about specific trees.

lines.text: The trees in the park are green – the article is needed because you have specified

spans.text: The trees in the park are green
– the article is needed because you have specified

lines.text: which trees you are talking about.

spans.text: which trees you are talking about.

lines.text: Indefinite article (a/an)
If the noun is singular and countable, and this is the first time you have mentioned it, then you will

spans.text: If the noun is singular and countable, and this is the first time you have mentioned it, then you will

lines.text: usually need the indefinite article:
I bought a book – we do not know which book.

spans.text: – we do not know which book.

lines.text: There is a bird outside – we do not know anything about the bird.

spans.text: – we do not know anything about the bird.

lines.text: Measurements and rates also take the indefinite article: Three times a week

spans.text: Measurements and rates also take the indefinite article:

lines.text: If the noun starts with a vowel sound, then the article an is used: an ear , an uncle, an hour

spans.text: If the noun starts with a vowel sound, then the article

lines.text: If the noun starts with a consonant sound, then the article a is used: a school, a university

spans.text: If the noun starts with a consonant sound, then the article

lines.text: Definite article (the)
If your reader or listener understands what you are referring to, then you will usually need the

spans.text: If your reader or listener understands what you are referring to, then you will usually need the

lines.text: definite article:
I bought a book last week. The book is about trees.

spans.text: I bought a book last week. The book is about trees.

lines.text: (You have just mentioned the book, so you both know which one.)

spans.text: (You have just mentioned the book, so you both know which one.)

lines.text: We went to a wedding yesterday. The bride wore a lovely dress.

spans.text: We went to a wedding yesterday. The bride wore a lovely dress.

lines.text: (You have not mentioned the bride before, but you both know she is connected to

spans.text: (You have not mentioned the bride before, but you both know she is connected to

lines.text: the wedding.)
Some things are taken to be common knowledge in English and therefore take the definite article:

spans.text: Some things are taken to be common knowledge in English and therefore take the definite article:

lines.text: Decades – He was born in the 1920s .
Currencies – The dollar is getting stronger against the pound .
Superlatives and ordinals – The second book in the series is the best .
Oceans, seas and many rivers – The Nile flows into the Mediterranean .
Plural or ‘united’ countries – The Maldives are much smaller than the United States of America .
Adjectives used as nouns – The poor will always be a challenge for the rich in any country.

spans.text: will always be a challenge for

lines.text: Many organisations – The World Health Organization has a detailed definition of health.

spans.text: has a detailed definition of health.

lines.text: A scientific categorisation – The zebra is native to Africa.
A symbol – The Merlion is a symbol of Singapore.
Unique people, places or things – The prime minister said she would call a conference on

spans.text: said she would call a conference on

lines.text: changes affecting the earth’s climate.
Unique adjectives – The same people always take the only parking spaces available.
Other word patterns which take ‘the’:
Specific nouns modified by a relative clause – The paintings (which are) in the gallery

spans.text: Specific nouns modified by a relative clause –

lines.text: Specific nouns followed by ‘of’. This is a very common pattern - The use of this procedure

spans.text: Specific nouns followed by ‘of’. This is a very common pattern -

lines.text: Plural nouns preceded by ‘of’ – e.g. Some of the paintings were interesting.
Common error: You cannot write most of paintings or none of paintings .
It is either most of the paintings (definite) or most paintings (general) .
Most of the paintings in the exhibition were landscapes.

spans.text: Most of the paintings in the exhibition were landscapes.

lines.text: (definite – we know which specific paintings – they are in the exhibition)

spans.text: (definite – we know which specific paintings – they are in the exhibition)

lines.text: Most paintings nowadays (general – not specific paintings)
No article
We do not need an article if a noun is plural or uncountable and it is not definite.

spans.text: We do not need an article if a noun is plural or uncountable and it is not definite.

lines.text: Women generally live longer than men.

spans.text: Women generally live longer than men.

lines.text: Articles are difficult to use.
Paint is hard to remove.
Exercise
Try this exercise, putting a/an/the in the blanks. If there should be no article, then place a * in the

spans.text: Try this exercise, putting a/an/the in the blanks. If there should be no article, then place a * in the

lines.text: blank. The answers and explanations follow.

spans.text: blank. The answers and explanations follow.

lines.text: Answers
Mr Coleman was (1) a very fastidious person. He lived three (2) * streets away from us, in

spans.text: very fastidious person. He lived three (2)

lines.text: (3) a small house with (4) a beautiful garden. Having taken early retirement from his (5) * job as (6)

spans.text: beautiful garden. Having taken early retirement from his (5)

lines.text: a button counter, he now had plenty of time to worry, and this he did very successfully. He often

spans.text: button counter, he now had plenty of time to worry, and this he did very successfully. He often

lines.text: spent sleepless nights trying to figure out how he could successfully cook both sides of (7) an

spans.text: spent sleepless nights trying to figure out how he could successfully cook

lines.text: omelette without it breaking, or how he might achieve better access to (8) the tins at (9) the back

spans.text: omelette without it breaking, or how he might achieve better access to (8)

lines.text: of his cupboard. (10) * Most of his home was exceptionally neat and tidy, but several loose cables

spans.text: Most of his home was exceptionally neat and tidy, but several loose cables

lines.text: behind (11) the television set bothered him, and he never quite knew what to do with (12) * empty

spans.text: television set bothered him, and he never quite knew what to do with (12)

lines.text: plastic bags.
Then, one day, his life changed, and he began to experience some relief from his anguish.

(2) no article plural, countable noun; a number is used instead (‘three streets’)
